My least favorite game of all time. You wait slowly for everyone to draft roles from a hand one at a time, then people reveal their roles and your turn is skipped, so you wait as everyone slowly takes their turn one at a time. Just a truly horrible design.

If the drafting of roles and the turn-taking was simultaneous, it could at least be a short, chaotic game, and losing a turn wouldn't sting that much. Instead, it can be 10-15 minutes between your turns if you get unlucky. I will NEVER play this game again.

Update 5+ years later: I played this game again, with a smaller, quicker group. It still SUCKED. The entire concept of the Warlord where you can move yourself farther from victory just to screw over someone else and make the game take longer for everyone is the kind of idea that should permanently get your game design license revoked. And at least let the player collect their little income if they get Assassined.

The basic concept is hilarious! Except the objective is to build boring structures for VPs, but that's acceptable for the amusing bluffing game. Though now that I think about it, the bluffing game is awfully restrained. Like it still works, but still so many of the jobs are about accumulating money and VPs. Like a euro with a tiny bit of interaction. There's something that bothers me, how the assassin/thief have no idea who they're targeting. That's the biggest part of the appeal, but being blind also makes it less mean, it was never anything personal! And that's the problem, it puts all interaction at arms length so nobody gets too offended by things going horribly wrong.

I think part of it is that the drafting of roles doesn't give enough information to reliably use groupthink against each other, so the attacks just feel like random chance. It came out much later, but Love Letter does the same concept with way more interaction, and less euro-building.

Analysis of a Meaningful Decision in Citadels

A card is burned. The King is looking at Assassin, Thief, Magician, King, Merchant, Architect, and Warlord.

THE KING
"Merchant is clearly the best card here. And I'm playing a Green. Nobody can refuse that money. So should I take Merchant? I dunno - the person who picks Assassin is likely to target the Merchant because he's so powerful. And the next guy knows I either have Bishop or Merchant. But maybe the next guy also knows that I know taking Merchant is extremely dangerous! So he'll figure Merchant was burned because there's no way I'd take something so risky! So I can take Merchant because he'll assassinate Bishop! But wait ... maybe HE KNOWS that I KNOW that he knows Merchant is risky! That means he'll choose to assassinate Merchant after all! ... ... ... In that case, what happens if I take Architect?"

Five minutes later.

THE KING
"Whatever, I'll just take Thief, which in retrospect is one of the most broken roles because you can name not Merchant or Architect and always succeed. Additionally, you force someone else to take Assassin and perform the communal necessity of naming Merchant or Architect."

LAST PLAYER
"Hmm, Merchant or Architect? Merchant is more powerful, but more likely to be assassinated. So I'd better take Architect. But wait! What if the Assassin knows that I know--"

What is with the hype on this one? The overall mechanisms of the game have promise, gold or cards, build buildings to make different roles better for you, usw; what it boils down to though, is a whole lot of punishment. You can't have a big hand or the magician will swap with you. You can't have a lot of gold, or the thief will hit you. You're in danger taking either of the better roles (Merchant and Architect) because the Assassin will be likely to hit you. And on, and on.

My A number one complaint with this game is that planning ahead is nigh impossible because of all the constant chaos that unfolds as the game progresses. I like a lot of the ideas that it has, but the reality of its implementation is just not to my tastes at all. The game presents the illusion of interesting choices (i.e.: I think I'll create card advantage by doing this) and then randomly punishes you and renders your planning useless. Funnily, games like Fluxx, which I consider about as random as this, are less offensive to me in the grand sense because at least Fluxx doesn't have the pretension of being a game where the decisions you make are all that important. Citadels does, and what it delivers is that much more annoying to me as a result. Quite easily my least favourite game put out by both HiG and European design firms in general.

While there is something to the character drafting system, the rest of the game falls flat. The core gameplay of taking money and building districts is just boring, which is not something you want to be saying about a game where winning feels so random.
The feel-bad moments (getting assassinated) feel a lot worse than the good moments (uhh... stealing someone else's cards?) feel good.

And 80+% of the time, you're just waiting for someone else's turn. This is a game that tricks you into playing with a high player count and then greatly overstays its welcome. Last couple times I played I regretted it before the first round was over.

The secret role selection is an intriguing solution to the problem of game attacks feeling personal... you don't even know who you're attacking! You try, of course, but if you mean to attack someone and succeed, it's kinda their fault for being predictable. That's interesting!

But it still feels bad being kneecapped. And at 7p it took almost two hours. And tearing the leader down to prevent the game from ending is a dynamic I think gaming has outgrown. And and and. I hated it. I respect it a little, but I still hated it!

Finally got around to playing this a couple times with larger groups (at least 5 players) and it was a bit of a let down. Seems like it should have been great at those higher player counts but it just wasn't.

The core dilemma of the game is that you want to build valuable buildings but collecting lots of money means you are risking the thief stealing from you. And not only that, by having lots of money you draw attention to yourself, so you have to be extra sneaky in choosing a role.

This in an of itself is great. The problem is when the player count gets high, and therefore the interplay of roles is most interesting (since most roles are out there) you can often just get by on luck. And when you do get caught it really hurts. Almost certainly, a couple players get picked on our of sheer luck, and are totally taken out of the running through no fault of their own. This is one of my least favorite features of a game.

The basic mechanic has nice intrigue, but I view the thief/assassin as pretty fatal to the enjoyment of the game. The best games are the ones where fun is had by all and in this game you have the opposite: a near-guarantee that someone will not have any fun.

A mix of card-based set collection and a hidden role draft adding some interaction with plenty of bluffing. With a group that knows the rules well and can keep the game moving, there's a bit of fun to be had here, but I've played it too often with groups where most people are new and I think it's a bit rough in those situations.

This is one of those rare games that is good both with two players and with many players. The mechanics of the game change slightly between games with 2 or 3 players and those with 4 or more. As a result, both are very interesting games to play and I'm looking forward to many more plays of this.

One thing about this game though, the time to play seems to be directly related to the number of players in the game. A two player game only takes 20 minutes or so, but a seven player game easily takes over an hour. In fact, 10 minutes per player is probably a good rule of thumb, longer if just learning the game.

Edit: This was one of the first "modern" board games I played. I still enjoy it, but not quite as much as I did six years ago. Lowering the rating just a bit to reflect that.

Edit: Lowering the rating further to reflect that the only reason I'd play this edition of the game is that it is the only edition we own. Would rather play the newer edition, but not enough to add it to our collection.

The original European version (published in 2000 as Ohne Furcht und Adel) only contained the basic eight roles (for up to seven players). When the American edition was published in 2002 it added both a ninth role to facilitate an eighth player, and an alternate role for each of those nine, a total of eighteen roles, only eight of which are in any game, (or nine for an eight player game). There were also two rule changes: a player could not have more than one identical district in their city, and if a player chooses the King and is assassinated they still get the Crown (albeit not until the end of the round).

I don't understand why there aren't two different BoardGameGeek entries for these when there is a 2016 version of Citadels adding a third set of potential role that does get a separate BGG entry.

The other interesting difference between those two versions is that the plastic gold tokens in the initial version were replaced by cardboard tokens because the publishers were afraid a child could mistake the plastic ones for butterscotch candy and choke to death. I note that the "butterscotch candy" style gold pieces was restored in the 2016 reprint.

Boardgamegeek now considers Citadels to be a "card drafting" game, but that term didn't exist when it was first published in 2000. The earliest game I consider to be "card drafting" is the 2004 game Fairy Tale, where all players draft concurrently. I believe the reason I don't think of Citadels as a drafting game is because players take turns choosing one role card from a shrinking set of role cards, and because it has so much more going on than just the drafting, the roles being drafted having so much variety to them.

Some roles enhance the controlling player's ability to obtain more gold, and other roles hamper other players either directly, (Warlord), or indirectly as the controller of other roles, (Assassin, Thief). So one must choose a role that is profitable and doesn't attract the attention of the other roles that can cause harm.

The overall goal is to obtain the most victory points by using one's gold to purchase districts. The more expensive the district, the more victory points it gives.

I think Citadels is best with more players, as then fewer roles are skipped each turn. With seven or eight players, the only skipped role is the one randomly and secretly removed each turn to make it harder to guess which role other players have chosen.
